Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 21, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Miscellaneous Application No. 120 of 1954.
This is an appeal by special leave against the decision of the Allahabad High Court dismissing the appellants application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.
The High Court in dismissing his application came to the conclusion that the appellant had not been dismissed or removed from service and that Art. 311 of the Constitution did not apply

arguments.claim: The appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agricultural Service.

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us on behalf of the appellant that at no time was he confirmed in any post either in the Subordinate Agricultural Service or in the United Provinces Agricultural Service Class II. In our opinion, the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agricultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a correct finding.

arguments.claim: Termination of the services of a person employed by the Government does not amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service, as per Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India and Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of this Court in Satish Chandra Anand v. The Union of India and in Shyam Lal v. The State of Uttar Pradesh clearly establish that termination of the services of a person employed by the Government does not amount in all cases to dismissal or removal from service.

arguments.claim: The termination of the appellant's services under r. 25(4) does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the appellant was employed in a temporary capacity in the Subordinate Agricultural Service and was shown in the Gradation List as on probation. His conditions of service were governed by the Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules. Rule 25(4) of these Rules permits the Director of Agriculture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months notice if that person has not made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction.

arguments.claim: In principle, there cannot be any clear distinction between the termination of the services of a person under the terms of a contract governing him and the termination of his services in accordance with the terms of his conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: The termination of the appellants services under r. 25(4) does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant. In principle, we cannot see any clear distinction between the termination of the services of a person under the terms of a contract governing him and the termination of his services in accordance with the terms of his conditions of service.

arguments.claim: Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank.

anchor.surface_text: The order complained against did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order. Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank.

arguments.claim: The appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

holdings.text: The termination of the appellant's services under r. 25(4) does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the appellant was employed in a temporary capacity in the Subordinate Agricultural Service and was shown in the Gradation List as on probation. His conditions of service were governed by the Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules. Rule 25 4 of these Rules permits the Director of Agricul- ture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months notice if that person has not made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction. The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4 does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents in Satish Chandra Anand and Shyam Lal; applies r.25(4) allowing termination by notice for probationers whose work is unsatisfactory; such terminations per service rules are not punitive.

holdings.text: In principle, there cannot be any clear distinction between the termination of the services of a person under the terms of a contract governing him and the termination of his services in accordance with the terms of his conditions of service.

anchor.surface_text: The termination of the appellants services under r. 25(4) does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant. In principle, we cannot see any clear distinction between the termination of the services of a person under the terms of a contract governing him and the termination of his services in accordance with the terms of his conditions of service.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonizes treatment of contractual employment termination (precedent) with service rules-based termination to deny Art.311 protection when per terms.

holdings.text: Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank.

anchor.surface_text: The order complained against did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order. Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does not per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is not his substantive rank. For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary officiating post does not alter substantive rank; reversion to substantive post not reduction unless punitive.

holdings.text: The appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence adduced to show punitive intent; lacks proof required to trigger Art.311(2) reduction in rank protection.

holdings.text: The finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agricultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a correct finding.

anchor.surface_text: It was conceded before us on behalf of the appellant that at no time was he confirmed in any post either in the Subordinate Agricultural Service or in the United Provinces Agricultural Service Class II. In our opinion, the finding of the High Court that the appellant had failed to establish that he was confirmed as a member of the Subordinate Agricultural Service, based upon the materials before it, was a correct finding.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Review of record and concession confirm no permanent/confirmed status; temporary throughout.

holdings.text: The further finding of the High Court that the appellant's contention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had not been substantiated appears to us also to be a correct finding upon the materials on the record.

anchor.surface_text: The further finding of the High Court that the appellants contention that he had been absorbed in the permanent cadre of the United Provinces Agricultural Service had not been substantiated appears to us also to be a correct finding upon the materials on the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of substantiation on record for absorption claim; remained temporary.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the appellant was employed in a temporary capacity in the Subordinate Agricultural Service and was shown in the Gradation List as on probation. His conditions of service were governed by the Subordinate Agriculture Service Rules. Rule 25 4 of these Rules permits the Director of Agricul- ture to terminate the services of a person on probation by giving him one months notice if that person has not made sufficient use of his opportunities or if he has otherwise failed to give satisfaction. The termination of the appellants services under r. 25 4 does not amount to dismissal or removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 as it was in accordance with the terms of the conditions of service applicable to the appellant.

The order companyplained against did number companytravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was therefore a valid order. Reversion from a temporary post held by a person does number per se amount to reduction in rank because the temporary post held by him is number his substantive rank. For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of this appeal it is unnecessary to decide in what circumstances a reversion would be regarded as reduction in rank as the appellant has not established as a fact that the order of reversion passed against him was by way of a penalty. The order of reversion, therefore, did not contravene the provisions of Art. 311 and was a valid order.
